newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russia's Yasin says T-bill tax will be passed.
newsitem.headline: Russia's Yasin says T-bill tax will be passed.

text.p: The State Duma, the lower house of the Russian parliament, is likely to pass a 15 percent profit tax on government securities operations and interest on household deposits in banks, Economy Minister Yevgeny Yasin said on Wednesday.
"This will increase the revenue part of the budget and the Duma has a great appetite for spending," Yasin told a meeting of the American Chamber of Commerce.
Yasin said the government no longer needed tax exemptions on government securitities operations introduced at the start of trade in 1993 to attract buyers.
Finance Minister Alexander Livshits said on Tuesday that the proposed tax may not make it through parliament, as there were many opponents to the draft.
Central bank chairman Sergei Dubinin said last week that the bank would oppose the tax and if levied it would lead to a rise in the yield necessary to raise resources for the government.

At Wednesday's auction of six-month discount GKO Treasury bills the average yield fell to 61.25 percent, and the government says it wants yields to fall to 25-50 percent this year. In the run-up to the June/July presidential election they topped 200 percent.
